messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 21, 2018 - February 27, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-02-28T21:35:01Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-02-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-02-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180228-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period with no significant flares or CMEs.
    
Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-02-23T09:00Z-12:00Z and 2018-02-27T03:00Z-06:00Z. These slight increases in geomagnetic activity were associated with the arrival of coronal hole high speed streams detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-02-22 and 2018-02-26, respectively. Solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2018-02-23 and 2018-02-27.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a couple coronal hole high speed streams around 2018-02-21 and 2018-02-26, respectively.  Solar wind speed reached values of >650 km/s on 2018-02-22 and 2018-02-27.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the reporting period, but it was elevated around 2018-02-21.  This increase in the electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt was possibly associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-02-16.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-02-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-03-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are currently two active regions visible at the surface of the sun that could produce some flare or CME activity. An increase in geomagnetic activity is possible in the next few days due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream originating from the northern coronal hole seen in SDO images close to disk center around 2018-02-28.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 14, 2018 - February 20, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-02-21T22:40:12Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-02-14T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-02-20T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180221-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:


Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period with no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-02-19T00:00Z-03:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-02-16. Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2018-02-18.

There was a CME arrival detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-02-15T07:38Z attributed to the CME starting at 2018-02-12T01:25Z (see notifications 20180212-AL-001, 20180213-AL-001 and 20180215-AL-001).  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-02-16.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2018-02-17. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-02-19T16:05Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notification 20180219-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-02-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-02-27T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There is only one active region currently visible at the surface of the sun that could produce some flare or CME activity. A slight increase in geomagnetic activity is possible in the next few days due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream originating from the coronal hole seen in SDO images close to disk center on 2018-02-21.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-02-21T21:53:06Z
## Message ID: 20180221-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with ID 20180219-AL-001. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-02-19T16:05Z and remain at about 80% of the threshold, currently near 87,000 pfu. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by high speed stream starting at 2018-02-16T10:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-02-19T16:05:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-02-19T15:43:57Z
## Message ID: 20180219-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-02-19T16:05Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-02-16T10:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-02-19T16:05:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-02-15T14:59:46Z
## Message ID: 20180215-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by ACE at L1 at 2018-02-15T07:50Z. 

The shock is caused by a CME with ID 2018-02-12T01:25:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20180212-AL-001, 20180213-AL-001). Magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm expected.


Activity ID: 2018-02-15T07:50:00-IPS-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 07, 2018 - February 13, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-02-14T20:09:04Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-02-07T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-02-13T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180214-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There was 1 C-type CME (see details below) originating from AR 12699. Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that this CME may affect Osiris and missions near Earth. The leading edge of the CME will reach Osiris at about 2018-02-15T02:40Z (plus minus 7 hours) and NASA missions near Earth at about 2018-02-15T06:42Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notifications 20180212-AL-001 and 20180213-AL-001).  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2018-02-12T01:25Z     ~554            C                22/-7                49                          SOHO, STEREO A                    


Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-02-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-02-20T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are several active regions currently visible on the solar surface that could produce some flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate. An increase in geomagnetic activity is expected to occur around 2018-02-15 due to the expected arrival of the CME mentioned above followed by the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (Osiris, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-02-13T12:56:57Z
## Message ID: 20180213-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME(s) with ID(s) 2018-02-12T01:25:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20180212-AL-001). Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Out of 32 ensemble members (see notes section), 26 (81%) indicate impact at NASA missions near Earth. Ensemble simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2018-02-14T12:00Z and 2018-02-15T12:38Z (average arrival 2018-02-15T02:16Z). The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 82% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 2-4 range (below minor to below minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2018-02-12_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX067/20180212_012500_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX067_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2018-02-12_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX067/20180212_012500_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX067_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2018-02-12_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX067/20180212_012500_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX067_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2018-02-12_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX067/20180212_012500_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX067_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at SWRC is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2018-02-12_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX067/Detailed_results_20180212_012500_ncmes1_sims32_HILOX067.txt
###


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Osiris, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-02-12T15:37:33Z
## Message ID: 20180212-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2018-02-12T01:25Z.

Estimated speed: ~554 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 49 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 22/-7 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2018-02-12T01:25:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Osiris.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Osiris at 2018-02-15T02:40Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2018-02-15T06:42Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2018-02-12T01:25:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20180212_072100_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20180212_072100_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20180212_072100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20180212_072100_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2018-02-12T01:25:00-CME-001) is associated with a C1.5 flare with ID 2018-02-12T00:15:00-FLR-001 which peaked at 2018-02-12T01:35Z.

S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 31, 2018 - February 06, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-02-07T23:25:11Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-01-31T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-02-06T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180207-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

 
Solar activity was at low level during this reporting period with no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-01-31T21:00Z-24:00Z, 2018-02-05T00:00Z-03:00Z and 2018-02-05T12:00Z-15:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of two coronal hole high speed streams detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-01-31 and 2018-02-04, respectively. Solar wind speed reached values of ~450 km/s on 2018-02-01 and 2018-02-06.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-02-06.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~550 km/s on 2018-02-06. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-02-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-02-13T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are several small active regions currently present on the solar surface.  The most recent one, AR 12699, has shown enhanced activity and could produce flare or CME activity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 24, 2018 - January 30, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-01-31T21:50:03Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-01-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-01-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180131-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low level during this reporting period with no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-01-24T21:00Z-24:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-01-24. Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2018-01-26.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-01-24. Solar wind speed reached values of >600 km/s on 2018-01-27. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-01-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-02-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There is only one small active region currently visible on the solar disk that could produce some flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate. A slight increase in geomagnetic activity may occur around 2018-02-05 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream from the northern coronal hole seen on the Earth's facing solar disk around 2018-01-31.
